reviewText:
*UPDATE: Got a Real Tone Cable now. Much better. Preparing Rocksmith 2014 review too*
As I was looking ways to learn guitar because I bought a Les Paul recently made me look into Rocksmith, a blend of a learning software and a game that in a sort of way reminds of a Rockband or Guitar Hero but complex and versatile at the time.
I plugged my guitar as I started the game, and it said to me after reaching the main screen I needed a Real Tone Cable as it specified in the store page. It wasn't a problem, as you CAN USE OTHER SOFTWARE to emulate the Real Tone effect so the game can recognise your guitar and then, let you play the game. You have to search the software in the internet and it makes you play outside Steam (that's why I have 5 min played, but I have played several hours) and if you want to be inside Steam while playing, you have to add the shortcut to your Library. Without the Real Tone Cable there is NO WAY to play inside Steam.
I still recommend buying the Real Tone Cable if you have the money to, because the other software can sometimes crash in a middle of a song or event and that ruins the experience of it. If you get the latest patch of the software, it will crash once in a while.

Talking about the music, the game offers a big catalog of songs (including a lot of genres like metal,classic rock, rock, alternative,etc) that grow smaller as you learn them all (but that will take quite a while though!) and a really extense one of DLC that is, in my opinion, somewhat better than the original because you buy the songs depending on your taste of music. I often buy my DLC during a sale since each song cost 1.49$ then and you can buy a lot more.

The gameplay is fantastic. The different modes that a song has include Practice,Perform,Riff Repeater and Techniques Used (and the great Master Mode unlocked after 100.000 points achieved in a song) The most valuable for me was the Riff Repeater, as you have 3 other options inside of it called Free Speed, Leveler and Accelerator (You can also manipulate the speed and level of the section) Those 3 help you to practice different sections of a song without trouble letting you do a first test to know your current level of playing the section, and then giving you 30 attempt to play the section at perfection. Losing lives after lives make you really try to play the section correctly!

At the end, play Rocksmith and you will have a great time as you learn the instrument you love with tons of hours of gameplay. Highly recommended for pros or starters.

reviewText:
I have played guitar for many years and got this as a way to keep my chops up while not currently playing in a band. The verdict: it works! I recorded the same guitar part before and after about a dozen hours of playing the game's career mode and there was clearly an improvement in both my timing and phrasing--also the number of tries it took me to get a decent take when from like fifteen to one or two. I maybe would have seen the same result practicing along w/ a metronome but this seemed like more fun.

The one major caveat for experienced players--esp. ones like myself who have never played anything like
Guitar Hero--is that this is entirely unlike how most people typically learn to play songs. Normally, you learn part A, B, C and D or whatever and then the solos if you want and piece them together. This just throws sort of a fake book simplified version of the entire song at you all at once. As  you get better, it starts to fill in the notes until you are playing the actual guitar part. It's strange and sometimes frustrating but if you keep plugging away you will get through and eventually you learn to read the game's kinda 3D, color-coded tablature quite well and the process becomes quicker.

My other complaints would be it can be a bit too lenient on timing and sometimes it lets you fudge chords. If you let the game's scoring dictate how you play, that can lead to bad habits. You need to show discipline on your own and play the parts correctly even if you can cheat a little and get a better score. Also, even using a relatively high end pro-sumer type soundcard (Focusrite Scarlett), there is a slight delay to the audio which you get used to but is enough to be annoying. It reminds me of playing on a digital guitar amp circa-2000, more of a feel thing but that matters.

Overall though, this is a fun way to practice and I've found myself playing guitar more both with and without the game. I am just letting the game pick what songs to learn and am finding even the songs I don't like are actually fun to play. Also, like most people, practicing on my own, I tend to just practice the things I am good at and letting the game pick songs forces me out of my comfort zone. Definitely check this out if you are looking to improve your existing guitar skills.

reviewText:
I'd always laughed at THOSE games. You know the ones. Guitar Hero, DJ Hero, Triangle Hero, Tamborine Hero, Kazoo Quest, etc etc. However a year ago I finally got up to date on the Donkey Kong rhythm platform game on the Gamecube. In this, you use bongos to control attacks, movement and jumping.. you really feel like a monkey, bashing away at those bongos.But anyway, that got me thinking how cool ACTUAL music is as a control/input/interface method for gaming. Then, I found out about this.

Unlike those lame Flute Quest Hero games, in this, you don't have a plastic flute or french horn or scratch turntable, but rather the actual musical equivalent. For this game, it is focused so far on guitar and bass. I am using a 7 string guitar, in a different  tuning to the game. My guitar was set up for this drop F tuning, so I was worried at first it might not like my guitar.. well, it wasn't an issue. There are stickers provided in the box that allow you to set the numbers of your frets via stickers on your guitar, so for me that was perfect, moving the frets up 2 spaces and ignoring my 7th/lowest string, I can play the game fine. Harmonics are a little tricky tho, but can always tune up for those tracks/parts..

In its essence, this is the best way to learn guitar. The best way for guitarists of any skill level to play along with other people's tunes, as well as for experienced guitarists to have a program with which to assess and further develop your existing skills.

The DLCs are great, a little bit of metal is available - Pantera, Lamb Of God and some oldies like Megadeath.. some indie rock like Pixies, but mostly this is about rock, new and classic.

There is a multiplayer aspect, but it's only local and you need to get two cables for it.. wondering if latency would increase due to extra guitar or bass input..

Also if you want to practice bass on a guitar, it has an octave pedal to 'emulate' bass on guitar. It's a pity there is no online multiplayer, but there is leaderboard scoring.

Not to mention there is an updated version RS2014 coming out in rOcktober, with support for different tunings (only found standard and drop D so far in the game).

There's a lot that could come to this game and a lot that is already in there so it's hard to describe everything. I dream of one day there being mod support for this title, or plugin/addon support by community producers. At the moment however there is a large range of DLC tunes you can purchase for $3.50 USD (in my region) each.. not a bad price to own a song, but also to have the tablature and a program to help you learn it :)

The latency is a bit of an issue at first, but once fiddling with the ini or game settings, you can get something reasonable.. seems to be somewhere around 30-200ms range depending on settings, but it can be worse if you don't follow the set up guides or have a cruddy PCI/PCI-E soundcard or a slow computer.

There's a lot to recommend about this game - support it and throw away any other music games you have that involve plastic. Why learn how to play a peace of plastic when you can play the real thing..

While it is harder to get into it, if you don't have an electric guitar or bass (obviously this is required for the game, but it doesn't mention it on the system requirements on the back, LOL!) it might be a bit of cost to buy one to play this.. but still, I think I would have learnt A LOT quicker when I started playing guitar 15 years ago, if I had've had this tool at my disposal then. The marketing is true - it IS the quickest and easiest way to learn guitar, I fully endorse that.

However if you are not sure guitar is for you, also if you are younger or have softer hands/skin, it might be worth starting out on a cheap nylon string acoustic before moving to steel string electric..

I've seen 2014 played and there is a lot of improvement in the interface, pickup and subtlety of the game, but Rocksmith still holds its own. This game has some really great points, but some possible, yet inherent, downsides. I have played guitar for more than a decade, and despite my bias against the whole idea of a videogame as a learning tool, this manages to be a fun game and a decent learning tool. I would not reccomend it for somebody who has just bought a guitar and is just now learning simple because one could become entirely dependent—for learning—upon the mechanisms in the game instead of learning to read sheet music or tab. Anybody who has played for more than a month would most likely benefit from it assuming he/she had sufficient knowledge on basic chords and a elementary understanding of scales. The game will teach quite well, and will introduce a varied array of topics such as vibrato and harmonics with mini-lessons. Because of this, one must ensure that the styles and genres represented by the songs that come with the game are appealing and represent where he/she would like to be musically in the future. Even if the songs are unappealing, they serve to encompass a variety of technical skills; as long as one ensures that he/she is utilizing proper form, technique, and rythym, his/her use of the game should yield a well rounded guitar player. The songs are also fairly easy; learning from rock music is much easier than learning from a more demanding style, so use it as a launching pad to get started—even if rock isn't the first choice. Just don't expect the game to provide motivation—it's only going to roughly assess the player and provide the next step, which can be extremely difficult when one is teaching himself or herself.

If you have an electric guitar laying around and wouldn't mind learning how to play, this is a great way to start.
I've been teaching myself for about five years now and purchased Rocksmith on the grounds of learning some songs I have a hard time finding tabs for online. Though I wanted to jump to the hardest difficulty to get a 100% accurate tab instead of every other note in a song, the game insists on taking it easy and adding difficulty as you play along and presumably get better.

I'm a bit stubborn so I was a little unsure about this at first- but this is how improvements are made. You PRACTICE. So as I played, I noticed songs gradually start adding more notes as opposed to the simple starting fragments. This system works great. There's also tons of little games to sharpen certain skills.

The best feature in my book, strangely enough, became the settings for all the amps. As the owner of an amp with just-alright sound settings, having a ton of new sounds and effects to work with was awesome. I have actually found myself: plugging the guitar into my computer to fire up the game, selecting an in-game amp setting, then plugging my headphone jack into the aux. on my amp, and using Rocksmith as my new amp at the volume of my real amp.

Rocksmith is a valuable asset for someone who already plays guitar as well as those interested in giving it a go. Give it a try!

Within 6 months of casual play I went from having absolutely no experience to mastering my first song; and I enjoyed pretty much every step along the way as the levelling system incrementally increased the difficulty to suit my level of ability.

It made practising a pleasure, which is crucial to developing your skills – more so than learning the numerous techniques that game teaches you and helps you to master.

The selection of songs is solid, and the vast amounts of DLC allow you to pick out some favourites to play.  This does, however, add to the cost a fair bit – and the fact that RS2014 charges to import the original game's songs to that version is pretty much charging you for the same content twice.  Thankfully that doesn't apply to the DLC songs.

The game does, unofficially, support custom (community made) songs; although these are of varying quality.

The game is an amazing technical achievement, and Ubisoft's usual nickel-and-diming doesn't detract from that.

I've been teaching myself for about five years now and purchased Rocksmith on the grounds of learning some songs I have a hard time finding tabs for online. Though I wanted to jump to the hardest difficulty to get a 100% accurate tab instead of every other note in a song, the game insists on taking it easy and adding difficulty as you play along and presumably get better.

I'm a bit stubborn so I was a little unsure about this at first- but this is how improvements are made. You PRACTICE. So as I played, I noticed songs gradually start adding more notes as opposed to the simple starting fragments. This system works great. There's also tons of little games to sharpen certain skills.

The best feature in my book, strangely enough, became the settings for all the amps. As the owner of an amp with just-alright sound settings, having a ton of new sounds and effects to work with was awesome. I have actually found myself: plugging the guitar into my computer to fire up the game, selecting an in-game amp setting, then plugging my headphone jack into the aux. on my amp, and using Rocksmith as my new amp at the volume of my real amp.

Rocksmith is a valuable asset for someone who already plays guitar as well as those interested in giving it a go. Give it a try!

The following is my review in pseudo FAQ format. Enjoy! :)

Why did I buy Rocksmith?

I bought this as a way to learn to play an electric guitar - something that I (and I suspect many others) have wanted to do since childhood but never really had the right tuition or couldn't quite follow along with a book/video. Mainly because you can't necessarily trust an instructor to be able to tell if you're hitting the right notes/chords and a book/video may assume a skill level or familiarity that you, as the learner, just do not possess.

Also, as per usual, it was in a sale and it's taken me at least a year to get around to buying a Real Tone cable once the price had come down in price to £20 on Amazon.

Do you actually learn how to play a guitar?

Yes. Yes you do.  You start with simple single note arrangements of songs, leading to complex single note arrangements and then on to a combination of single notes and chords before going to full chords.  The speed at which you do this depends on what Rocksmith thinks is best for you in terms of your actual ability, with arrangements being made simpler or harder (or truer to the actual song being played if you prefer).  You can also practice specific chords of a chosen song, any part of a song, different arrangements, or change songs in your setlist" to ones you're more familiar with and/or genres you prefer.

The game does not really support multiplayer as much as Guitar Hero. You can play gigs with your friends of course, switching the guitar every song, provided they have some guitar skills of their own. The learning curve of playing real guitar is still steaper than playing Guitar Hero, although the game supports a dynamic difficulty system, making it a little more accessible (but annoying if you want to really learn the proper way of playing a song, you're gonna have to unlock a master mode first). The game has some mini (arcade) games that do not require much skill and I guess those can provide for some multiplayer.
The best thing about it, is that it makes you want to keep on playing and practicing and this is a vital aspect of trying to learn to play any instrument really, so its really more recommendable to novice guitarists, who want to learn to play, but so far really can't seem to put the time and effort in.
